justification: In the Measures section the authors list “Personality-Big Five: IPIP-NEO-120 (Johnson, 2014),” and later explain that “The IPIP-NEO-120 is a scale used to measure a broad range of different personality traits … [that] correspond to the Big Five.”

Under Personality-Others the paper states “Grit Scale (Duckworth, Peterson, Matthews, & Kelly, 2007),” and further describes it as “a 12-item questionnaire used to measure passion and perseverance towards long-term goals.”

The questionnaire list includes “Dispositional Positive Emotion Scale (DPES) (Shiota, Keltner, & John, 2006),” and Supplementary Materials note it “is a 38-item questionnaire used to measure participant's disposition towards 7 different positive emotions.”

The Measures section names “Personal Need for Structure (Neuberg & Newsom, 1993),” and the description says it “is a 10-item questionnaire developed to measure individual differences in how much personal structure participants prefer to have in their lives.”

Within Personality-Others the authors list “Life History Strategy (Mini-K) (Figueredo et al., 2006),” stating it is “a 20-item questionnaire used to measure the seven domains of the Arizona Life History Battery.”

The scale roster includes “Life Orientation Test-Revised (LOT-R) (Scheier, Carver, & Bridges, 1994),” and the text specifies it is “used to measure individual differences in general optimism and pessimism.”

Under Cognitive measures the article cites “Rotter's Locus of Control (Rotter, 1966)” and explains it “contains 29 items measuring respondents’ tendency to think situations are under their own control or under the control of external events.”

The Cognitive section lists “Need for Cognition (Cacioppo & Petty, 1982),” noting it is “an 18-item questionnaire used to measure how much participants tend to engage in and enjoy effortful cognitive endeavors.”

measured_by: Santa Barbara Sense of Direction Scale
justification: Measures include “Santa Barbara Sense of Direction (Hegarty et al., 2006),” described as “a 15-item questionnaire used to measure self-reported spatial and navigational abilities.”
Decision-making measures list “Arnett Inventory of Sensation Seeking (AISS) (Arnett, 1994),” defined as “a 20-item questionnaire used to measure attitudes towards general sensation seeking.”
The authors include “Financial Risk Tolerance Assessment (Grable & Lytton, 1999)” among Decision-making instruments, indicating it assesses individual differences in financial risk tolerance.
Decision-making measures feature “Barratt Impulsivity Scale (BIS-11) (Patton, Stanford, & Barratt, 1995),” described as containing “30 questions measuring impulsiveness.”
The list names “Tolerance of Ambiguity (Stanley Budner, 1962),” a “16-item questionnaire measuring how tolerant participants are towards situations involving ambiguity.”

Decision-making instruments include “Interest/Deprivation Epistemic Curiosity Scale (I/D) (Litman, 2008),” identified as “a 10-item questionnaire … to measure pleasure from discovering new ideas and acquiring specific answers.”

The Measures section lists “Curiosity and Exploration Inventory (CEI-II) (Kashdan et al., 2009),” described as “a 10-item questionnaire used to measure feelings about and behavior towards curiosity and exploration.”

Social measures mention “Interpersonal Reactivity Scale (IRI) (Davis, 1983),” and the Supplementary text says it “is a 28-item questionnaire used to measure … perspective taking, fantasy, empathetic concern, and personal distress.”
construct: Empathy (perspective taking, fantasy, empathic concern, personal distress)

justification: The Social category lists “Revised Competitiveness (Harris & Houston, 2010),” noting it is “a 14-item questionnaire used to measure individual differences in competitiveness.”

measured_by: Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale
justification: Among Social scales the authors include “Fear of Negative Evaluation (Leary, 1983),” described as “a 12-item self-report questionnaire used to measure … how much participants experience fear when facing negative evaluations.”

The paper lists “Social and Economic Conservatism Scale (SECS) (Everett, 2013),” explaining it is “a 12-item self-report questionnaire used to measure attitudes towards various social, economic, and political topics.”

Social measures include “Collectivism/Individualism (Triandis & Gelfand, 1998),” with text noting it is “a 16-item self-report questionnaire used to measure individualistic versus collectivistic tendencies” including horizontal and vertical dimensions.

In the Discussion the authors state, “temporal discounting was measured by the Delay Discounting Questionnaire (Kirby, Petry, & Bickel, 1999),” which asks participants to choose between smaller-sooner and larger-later monetary rewards.
